risk_assessment.transmission: HKU5-CoV-2 can potentially infect human cells through ACE2 receptors, similar to SARS-CoV-2. The virus has been found in bats and appears capable of binding to human ACE2 receptors, suggesting potential for human-to-human transmission, although no human cases have been reported. Risk of transmission is a key concern based on the news articles.
risk_assessment.mortality: The provided articles do not mention any confirmed mortality rates or associated deaths from HKU5-CoV-2. However, it is stated that it’s similar to COVID-19 which is a cause for concern.
risk_assessment.mutation: The articles don’t discuss the mutation rate of the virus, but the fact that it is a coronavirus suggests it can mutate like other coronaviruses.
risk_assessment.containment: No information is provided in the articles about current containment efforts and therefore, the state is unknown. No human cases have been reported.
risk_assessment.treatment: The news reports do not mention any specific treatments for HKU5-CoV-2.
risk_assessment.summary: A new bat coronavirus, HKU5-CoV-2, has been discovered that has the potential to infect humans. Although there are no human cases reported, the discovery, the similarity to COVID-19, and its ability to bind to human ACE2 receptors raise significant concerns of another pandemic.

[H5 Bird Flu: Current Situation | Bird Flu | CDC - Centers for Disease ...](https://www.cdc.gov/bird-flu/situation-summary/index.html)
H5 bird flu is widespread in wild birds worldwide and is causing outbreaks in poultry and U.S. dairy cows with several recent human cases in U.S. dairy and poultry workers. While the current public health risk is low, CDC is watching the situation carefully and working with states to monitor people with animal exposures.

[CDC shares clinical and sequencing details from 3 recent human H5N1 cases](https://www.cidrap.umn.edu/avian-influenza-bird-flu/cdc-shares-clinical-and-sequencing-details-3-recent-human-h5n1-cases)
The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) today shared new sequencing findings on samples from two people with H5N1 avian flu infections, one a patient from Wyoming who was hospitalized after contact with backyard poultry and the other a dairy worker from Nevada. It also fleshed out clinical findings for the two patients, plus another from Ohio.
